docs.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va., June 11--Few people in the coal fields expect a heavy turnout of the United Mine Workers' 277,000 members on Tuesday when the union will vote to purge its laconic leader, Arnold R. Miller, or to continue his rule.

headline.main: Miners Apathetic as Union Votes Tuesday to Purge or Re-Elect Miller

docs.abstract: article on UMW union vote to purge or re-elect Miller; campaign activities of Patrick and Patterson discussed; illus of Miller and former Repr Ken Hechler (M)
docs.snippet: CHARLESTON, W.Va., June 11--Few people in the coal fields expect a heavy turnout of the United Mine Workers' 277,000 members on Tuesday when the union will vote to purge its laconic leader, Arnold R. Miller, or to continue his rule.

byline.original: By BEN A. FRANKLIN Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 9 The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that it is unconstitutional for states to insist that nonprescription contraceptives be sold only in drug stores or by doctors.

headline.main: High Court Voids New York Contraceptive-Sales Curb

docs.abstract: US Sup Ct, 7-2, rules it is unconst for states to insist that nonprescription contraceptives be sold only in drug stores or by drs and to prohibit ad of contraceptives; holds that states may not forbid persons under age 16 to get non-prescription contraceptives from anyone but dr; ruling comes in case involving NY statute restricting sale of contraceptives; decision is written by Justice William J Brennan Jr; possible ramifications discussed; Planned Parenthood Fed chmn Henrietta Marshall hails decision; 2 dissenters are Chief Justice Warren E Burger and William H Rehnquist (M)
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, June 9 The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that it is unconstitutional for states to insist that nonprescription contraceptives be sold only in drug stores or by doctors.

byline.original: By LESLEY OELSNER Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: When Bess Myserson left her job as New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, several companies saw an opportunity for a public relations coup if they could hire her as consumer adviser, spokesman or consultant. One auto manufacturer offered her $350,000, she says, to spend six days shooting advertisements. She turned it down.

headline.main: Bess Myerson's Advocacy A Business Matter Now; Bess Myerson's Advocacy Role Is in the Business Spotlight Now

docs.abstract: Bess Myerson, former NYC Comr of Consumer Affairs, in int, comments on her career as consumer consultant to business community; illus; Ellen Zawel, former pres of Consumers Cong, in int, comments on similar career with consulting firm of Jean Judge Assocs (M)
